title: Chelsea Tractors are SECOND biggest cause of rising carbon levels
text:
Increasing demand for SUVs is the second biggest contributor to the growth in carbon emissions, a new study has found.

Between 2010 and 2018, SUVs doubled their market share from 17 per cent to 39 per cent, prompting a rise in CO2 emissions.

Annual emissions from SUVs rose to more than 700 megatonnes of CO2, more than the combined emissions of the UK and the Netherlands.

Increasing demand for SUVs is the second biggest contributor to the growth in carbon emissions

Behind power, SUVs are the energy sector which drove the largest increase in emissions from 2010 to 2018

Apart from power, it is the energy sector which drove the largest increase in emissions, above heavy industry, aviation and shipping, according to The Guardian.

Laura Cozzi, the chief energy modeller of the International Energy Agency, which is behind the report, said: 'We were quite surprised by this result ourselves.'

It comes as smaller cars are pushing for lower emissions and electric vehicles, but this environmental improvement has been offset by the increasing demand for larger cars.

If SUV drivers were a country, they would be the seventh in the world for carbon emissions.

The average mass of all new cars rose 10 per cent between 2000 and 2016 showing a trend in preference for larger vehicles.

Florent Grelier from campaign group Transport and Environment said the poor aerodynamics combined with the size of the car make for bigger emissions.

He said: 'The problem is much bigger than we expected.'

If SUV drivers were a country, they would be the seventh in the world for carbon emissions

The SUV market has even bucked the trend of the stalling global car market, growing steadily since 2010

The SUV market has even bucked the trend of the stalling global car market which has been attributed to the China-US trade war.

The large vehicles sold a record 35million vehicles in 2018 with increased market share across the world.

In the US now, nearly one in two passenger cars sold is an SUV.

Popular models in the UK include the Nissan Qashqai, Hyundai Tucson and Land Rover Range Rover.

The government has pledged to ban the sale of new petrol and diesel cars from 2040, but hybrid models would be exempt under the plan.
